p: As compared to the extratropics, the intermodel range in the sensitivity of precipitation extremes is much larger in the tropics (Fig. 2), with close to zero sensitivity in some models and greater than 30 % K −1 in others. Additional reasons to doubt the response of tropical precipitation extremes in these global climate models include the large differences between tropical precipitation extremes in the twentieth-century simulations in different models [ 38], the inability of the models to represent mesoscale convective organization [ 72] or to simulate the interannual variability in tropical precipitation extremes when compared to observations [ 2, 3], and the disproportionate increases in precipitation extremes compared to other parts of the precipitation distribution that is found in some models—an “extreme mode” in the tropical response to climate change that relates to gridpoint storms [ 66, 67].
